Adding reasonCode, description params to close()

Refactoring WebSocketConnection

* More correctly handling closing behavior to handle edge cases that aren't exposed through testing with the Autobahn test suite.
* Using per-connection buffering debugger to be able to more easily trace the order of operations when investiating a problem.  (Only active when setting DEBUG environment variable)
* Drastically simplifying the fair distribution of message events emitted amongst connections.  Prevents a lot of data coming in all at once on a single connection from totally monopolizing the server's time before moving on to handling I/O on other sockets, rather than looping through and consuming all the buffered data for a single connection in one shot.
* Eliminating the outgoing frame queue which served no purpose except to create a useless, redundant extra buffer for outbound data.  Having that unnecessarily increased complexity, added undefined behavior around some edge cases, and didn't offer any benefit whatsoever.  There was some uncertainty regarding whether frames queued up to be sent would be discarded if the connection was closed.

Resolving Issue #72: subprotocol is converted to lowercase, problem if remote client is specifying in uppercase.
I'm still maintaining lower case subprotocol names internally, but now am maintaining a mapping in the request object to the exact subprotocol string requested by the client, so that exact string can be returned in the response.  This allows us to maintain case insensitivity in subprotocol names for practicality, but to return the exact casing of a subprotocol expected by the client.

Bug fix - parameter sanity check on parseCookies

During a websocket handshake, if the client does not pass a Cookie
header, then WebSocketRequest.prototype.readHandshake will pass an
undefined value to WebSocketRequest.prototype.parseCookies.

If the str parameter is undefined, then an exception will be thrown when
the .split() method is called upon it.

Merge pull request #62 from GICodeWarrior/xor

Add cstring include to native XOR.

Add cstring include to native XOR.

The previous includes are sufficient for Ubuntu and Mac, but for whatever
reason, cstring is necessary for memcpy on CentOS.

Implement deferred frame handling and a receive buffer limit.

If frame handling blocks the event loop longer than a given limit, defer the
next frame to the end of the event queue.  This reduces the opportunity for one
client to stall message handling for other clients.

Further, since frame handling is decoupled from the socket data event, a
receive buffer limit is included.  This limit indicates when the socket should
be pause()'ed, preventing the server from queuing many messages it isn't ready
to handle.

Fixing a couple minor issues reported by Patrick McManus:
- Indicating which version of Node the library is known to work with.
- Fixing bug in libwebsockets-test-server.js where the --port argument is both required and ignored.
Fixing potential DOS vulnerability when a client continually sends continuation frames without ever stopping.  It would eventually cause the server to run out of ram.. Fixed. yay.

Updating superficial details about the libwebsockets-test-server implementation

Lots of changes:
- Returning the connection object from the request object when you call accept()
- Adding a request router to allow multiple websocket applications to
  use the same server instance.  Requests are routed based on path and protocol
- Updated the WebSocketServer API to allow for the request router and to accept
  configuration options to tune the connection (max frame size etc)
- Adding a global 'close' event on the WebSocketServer instance that is fired
  whenever any client connection is closed.
- Reorganizing the libwebsockets-test-server implementation to integrate both
  the lws-mirror-protocol and dumb-increment-protocol into a single example
  server application.
